content.rendered:
Soft color palettes, non-sans-serif typefaces, centered typography… a serif-ically different range of Friday Likes this week with work from Barcelona, Helsinki, and Monterrey.

GrupCamera by Mucho

Based in Barcelona, Grup Camera is dedicated to classical music through various initiatives (and sub-brands), each with its own name and purpose. Designed by Mucho, this comprehensive identity is five different identities in one unified through a gorgeous, custom font that takes on a surprising amount of flavors depending on use. While all sub-brands have merit, the mint-to-pink gradient for the Falado concert series tingled my classical strings, if you know what I mean (because I don’t). See full project.

Torikorttelit by Kokoro & Moi

Known as Torikorttelit (Tori Quarters in English), the historical centre of Helsinki is “where the heart of the old town meets the new buzz of the city” and where colorful geometric patterns explode into a party of an identity designed by local firm Kokoro & Moi. The clash of the very graphic stripes and the serif logo is an interesting aesthetic that could best be described as “deadpan exuberance”. Perhaps this identity could be for anything, anywhere but it came together here and the world is a more joyful-looking place because of it. See full project.

Novelty by Anagrama

Novelty, in a suburb of Monterrey, Mexico, is “the high-end fashion store of curiosity shops” featuring hand-picked items from the world of fashion. Designed by perennial Friday Liker, Anagrama, who describe the identity as “sober and feminine but [having] the ability to thrive among more eccentric elements”, the soft color palette, luxurious typeface, and oddball watercolor splotches certainly add up to their description and the personality of the store. The matching, salmon-colored store furnishings bring it all together. See full project.
